remarks: Statement 12 in [Huneke] p. 2:  "Thus f(n) = (k - 1)f(n - 2) + k^(n-2)." - the number of the closed walks v(0) ... v(n-2) v(n-1) v(n) is the sum of the number of the closed walks v(0) ... v(n-2) v(n-1) v(n) with v(n-2) = v(n) (see ~ numclwwlk1 ) and with v(n-2) =/= v(n) ( see ~ numclwwlk2 ): f(n) = kf(n-2) + k^(n-2) - f(n-2) = (k - 1)f(n - 2) + k^(n-2) (Contributed by Alexander van der Vekens, 26-Aug-2018.)
